The **2001 State of Origin series** was the 20th year that the [annual three-
game series](/wiki/State_of_Origin_series "State of Origin series") between
the [Queensland](/wiki/Queensland_rugby_league_team "Queensland rugby league
team") and [New South Wales](/wiki/New_South_Wales_rugby_league_team "New
South Wales rugby league team") representative [rugby league
football](/wiki/Rugby_league_football "Rugby league football") teams was
contested entirely under '[state of origin](/wiki/State_of_origin "State of
origin")' selection rules. The series was notable for marking the first time
an England-based player was selected for State of Origin: Maroons legend
[Allan Langer](/wiki/Allan_Langer "Allan Langer") was asked to make his
comeback for the third and deciding match of the series and did so, helping
Queensland re-claim the shield in Brisbane.[1]

## Game
I[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2001_State_of_Origin_series&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Game I")]

Queensland stalwart coach [Wayne Bennett](/wiki/Wayne_Bennett_\(rugby_league\)
"Wayne Bennett \(rugby league\)") made it a personal mission to regain the
great loss of credibility suffered from the 2000 series whitewash and 40 point
last game defeat and decided he wanted his old Maroon coaching job back after
a two-year sojourn.

Sunday, May 6, 2001  
---  
[![Queensland colours.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Queensland_colours.svg/16px-Queensland_colours.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Queensland_colours.svg) [Queensland](/wiki/Queensland_State_of_Origin_Team "Queensland State of Origin Team") | 34–16  | [![New South Wales colours.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/New_South_Wales_colours.svg/16px-New_South_Wales_colours.svg.png)](/wiki/File:New_South_Wales_colours.svg) [New South Wales](/wiki/New_South_Wales_rugby_league_team "New South Wales rugby league team")  
---|---|---  
[Darren Lockyer](/wiki/Darren_Lockyer "Darren Lockyer") (**14** \- 1t,5g)  
[Darren Smith](/wiki/Darren_Smith_\(rugby_league\) "Darren Smith \(rugby
league\)") (**4** \- 1t)  
[John Buttigieg](/wiki/John_Buttigieg_\(rugby_league\) "John Buttigieg \(rugby
league\)") (**4** \- 1t)  
[John Doyle](/wiki/John_Doyle_\(rugby_league\) "John Doyle \(rugby league\)")
(**4** \- 1t)  
[Carl Webb](/wiki/Carl_Webb "Carl Webb") (**4** \- 1t)  
[Chis Walker](/wiki/Chris_Walker_\(rugby_league\) "Chris Walker \(rugby league\)") (**4** \- 1t)  | [(Report)](http://stats.rleague.com/rl/soo/game61.html) | (**4** \- 2g) [Michael De Vere](/wiki/Michael_De_Vere "Michael De Vere")   
(**4** \- 1t) [Matthew Gidley](/wiki/Matthew_Gidley "Matthew Gidley")  
(**4** \- 1t) [Brad Fittler](/wiki/Brad_Fittler "Brad Fittler")  
(**4** \- 1t) [Trent Barrett](/wiki/Trent_Barrett "Trent Barrett")  
[Suncorp Stadium](/wiki/Suncorp_Stadium "Suncorp Stadium"),
[Brisbane](/wiki/Brisbane "Brisbane")  
Attendance: 38,909  
Referee: [Bill Harrigan](/wiki/Bill_Harrigan "Bill Harrigan")  
Man of the Match: [Gorden Tallis](/wiki/Gorden_Tallis "Gorden Tallis")  
---  
  
In game I Queensland blooded no less than ten new players[2] and Wayne Bennett
gambled on the likes of [Brisbane Broncos](/wiki/Brisbane_Broncos "Brisbane
Broncos") forward [Carl Webb](/wiki/Carl_Webb "Carl Webb") and [North
Queensland Cowboys](/wiki/North_Queensland_Cowboys "North Queensland Cowboys")
[John Buttigieg](/wiki/John_Buttigieg_\(rugby_league\) "John Buttigieg \(rugby
league\)") and [John Doyle](/wiki/John_Doyle_\(rugby_league\) "John Doyle
\(rugby league\)") who were relative unknowns. But they each announced their
representative arrival in dramatic style with a try each in the first game,
won 34-16 by the Maroons in the last match played at the "old" [Suncorp
Stadium](/wiki/Suncorp_Stadium "Suncorp Stadium"). The most spectacular was
Webb's two minutes before half-time when he brushed off three defenders before
powering his way across the line.

## Game
II[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2001_State_of_Origin_series&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Game II")]

Queensland went into game 2 without captain [Gorden
Tallis](/wiki/Gorden_Tallis "Gorden Tallis") who was out with a neck injury.

Sunday, June 10, 2001  
---  
[![New South Wales colours.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/New_South_Wales_colours.svg/16px-New_South_Wales_colours.svg.png)](/wiki/File:New_South_Wales_colours.svg) [New South Wales](/wiki/New_South_Wales_rugby_league_team "New South Wales rugby league team") | 26–8  | [![Queensland colours.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Queensland_colours.svg/16px-Queensland_colours.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Queensland_colours.svg) [Queensland](/wiki/Queensland_State_of_Origin_Team "Queensland State of Origin Team")  
---|---|---  
[Brad Fittler](/wiki/Brad_Fittler "Brad Fittler") (**8** \- 2t)  
[Ryan Girdler](/wiki/Ryan_Girdler "Ryan Girdler") (**6** \- 3g)  
[Jamie Ainscough](/wiki/Jamie_Ainscough "Jamie Ainscough") (**4** \- 1t)  
[Trent Barrett](/wiki/Trent_Barrett "Trent Barrett") (**4** \- 1t)  
[Luke Ricketson](/wiki/Luke_Ricketson "Luke Ricketson") (**4** \- 1t)  | [(Report)](http://stats.rleague.com/rl/soo/game62.html) | (**4** \- 2g) [Darren Lockyer](/wiki/Darren_Lockyer "Darren Lockyer")   
(**4** \- 1t) [Chris Walker](/wiki/Chris_Walker_\(rugby_league\) "Chris Walker
\(rugby league\)")  
[Telstra Stadium](/wiki/Telstra_Stadium "Telstra Stadium"),
[Sydney](/wiki/Sydney "Sydney")  
Attendance: 70,249  
Referee: Bill Harrigan  
Man of the Match: [Trent Barrett](/wiki/Trent_Barrett "Trent Barrett")  
---  
  
Played before 70,000 at Telstra Stadium, Blues skipper [Brad
Fittler](/wiki/Brad_Fittler "Brad Fittler") scored two tries in what was to be
his last match for NSW on home soil and inspired his side to a 26-8 victory.
Man of the match was [Trent Barrett](/wiki/Trent_Barrett "Trent Barrett")
playing halfback for the first time due to injuries to [Brett
Kimmorley](/wiki/Brett_Kimmorley "Brett Kimmorley") and [Andrew
Johns](/wiki/Andrew_Johns "Andrew Johns"). Debutante [Mark
O'Meley](/wiki/Mark_O%27Meley "Mark O'Meley") was particularly impressive,
setting up Fittler's first try after 53 minutes with a smashing run that sent
defenders skittling.

## Game
III[[edit](/w/index.php?title=2001_State_of_Origin_series&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Game III")]

The lead up to Game III was dominated by emotion regarding [Brad
Fittler](/wiki/Brad_Fittler "Brad Fittler")'s pending retirement from
representative football after 29 Origin appearances. But with the series tied
at one game apiece Queensland needed some special emotion of their own to
avoid a loss. Without inspirational captain Tallis and an established halves
pairing, coach Bennett undertook furtive negotiations with Maroon's veteran
[Allan Langer](/wiki/Allan_Langer "Allan Langer"), then in his second English
season and captain of the [Warrington Wolves](/wiki/Warrington_Wolves
"Warrington Wolves"), and the rumours were only confirmed after Langer had
boarded a plane (under a false name) for the flight home, bound for his 31st
career Origin appearance.[3] At almost 35 years of age, Langer was named in
his famous No.7 jersey for the first time since leaving Australia part-way
through the [1999 NRL season](/wiki/1999_NRL_season "1999 NRL season").

Sunday, 1 July, 2001  
---  
[![Queensland colours.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Queensland_colours.svg/16px-Queensland_colours.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Queensland_colours.svg) [Queensland](/wiki/Queensland_State_of_Origin_Team "Queensland State of Origin Team") | 40–14[4] | [![New South Wales colours.svg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/New_South_Wales_colours.svg/16px-New_South_Wales_colours.svg.png)](/wiki/File:New_South_Wales_colours.svg) [New South Wales](/wiki/New_South_Wales_rugby_league_team "New South Wales rugby league team")  
---|---|---  
[Darren Lockyer](/wiki/Darren_Lockyer "Darren Lockyer") (**16** \- 2t,4g)  
[Chris Walker](/wiki/Chris_Walker_\(rugby_league\) "Chris Walker \(rugby
league\)") (**8** \- 2t)  
[Paul Bowman](/wiki/Paul_Bowman_\(rugby_league\) "Paul Bowman \(rugby
league\)") (**8** \- 2t)  
[Allan Langer](/wiki/Allan_Langer "Allan Langer") (**4** \- 1t)  
[Dane Carlaw](/wiki/Dane_Carlaw "Dane Carlaw") (**4** \- 1t)  | [(Report)](http://stats.rleague.com/rl/soo/game63.html) | (**14** \- 2t,3g) [Ryan Girdler](/wiki/Ryan_Girdler "Ryan Girdler")  
[ANZ Stadium](/wiki/Queensland_Sport_and_Athletics_Centre "Queensland Sport
and Athletics Centre"), [Brisbane](/wiki/Brisbane "Brisbane")  
Attendance: 49,441  
Referee: Bill Harrigan  
Man of the Match: [Darren Lockyer](/wiki/Darren_Lockyer "Darren Lockyer")  
---  
  
Despite NSW centre [Ryan Girdler](/wiki/Ryan_Girdler "Ryan Girdler") scoring
the fastest try in Origin history after 39 seconds, Queensland took a 28-8
lead into the break with Langer heavily involved in three of the Maroons'
first half tries. Alongside [Darren Lockyer](/wiki/Darren_Lockyer "Darren
Lockyer") who created his own form of havoc, Langer tore New South Wales to
shreds and capped his comeback in the 54th minute when he scored a trademark
solo try from close range to sentence the Blues to a series-deciding loss and
Fittler to his own bittersweet representative farewell (although he would make
a comeback [three years later](/wiki/2004_State_of_Origin_series "2004 State
of Origin series") and help his state to a victory in his final year before
retirement).

Sydney's _[The Daily Telegraph](/wiki/The_Daily_Telegraph_\(Sydney\) "The
Daily Telegraph \(Sydney\)")_ reacted to the New South Wales team's Origin
loss with this headline on the front of its paper on July 2, 2001: "BLOODY
ALF".[5]
